Fixed-Parameter Complexity of Minimum Profile Problems

Gregory Gutin Corresponding author. Department of Computer Science, Royal Holloway University of London, Egham, Surrey TW20 0EX, UK, gutin@cs.rhul.ac.uk and Department of Computer Science, University of Haifa, Israel    Stefan Szeider Department of Computer Science, Durham University Science Labs, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK, stefan.szeider@durham.ac.uk    Anders Yeo Department of Computer Science, Royal Holloway University of London, Egham, Surrey TW20 0EX, UK, anders@cs.rhul.ac.uk
Abstract

Let G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) be a graph. An ordering of G𝐺Gitalic_G is a bijection α:V→{1,2,…,|V|}.:𝛼→𝑉12…𝑉\alpha:\ V\mbox{$\rightarrow$}\{1,2,\ldots,|V|\}.italic_α : italic_V → { 1 , 2 , … , | italic_V | } . For a vertex v𝑣vitalic_v in G𝐺Gitalic_G, its closed neighborhood is N⁢[v]={u∈V:u⁢v∈E}∪{v}.𝑁delimited-[]𝑣conditional-set𝑢𝑉𝑢𝑣𝐸𝑣N[v]=\{u\in V:\ uv\in E\}\cup\{v\}.italic_N [ italic_v ] = { italic_u ∈ italic_V : italic_u italic_v ∈ italic_E } ∪ { italic_v } . The profile of an ordering α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of G𝐺Gitalic_G is prfα⁢(G)=∑v∈V(α⁢(v)−min⁡{α⁢(u):u∈N⁢[v]}).subscriptprf𝛼𝐺subscript𝑣𝑉𝛼𝑣:𝛼𝑢𝑢𝑁delimited-[]𝑣\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G)=\sum_{v\in V}(\alpha(v)-\min\{\alpha(u):\ u\in N[v]\}).prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α ( italic_v ) - roman_min { italic_α ( italic_u ) : italic_u ∈ italic_N [ italic_v ] } ) . The profile prf⁢(G)prf𝐺\mbox{prf}(G)prf ( italic_G ) of G𝐺Gitalic_G is the minimum of prfα⁢(G)subscriptprf𝛼𝐺\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G)prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) over all orderings α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of G𝐺Gitalic_G. It is well-known that prf⁢(G)prf𝐺\mbox{prf}(G)prf ( italic_G ) is the minimum number of edges in an interval graph H𝐻Hitalic_H that contains G𝐺Gitalic_G is a subgraph. Since |V|−1𝑉1|V|-1| italic_V | - 1 is a tight lower bound for the profile of connected graphs G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ), the parametrization above the guaranteed value |V|−1𝑉1|V|-1| italic_V | - 1 is of particular interest. We show that deciding whether the profile of a connected graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) is at most |V|−1+k𝑉1𝑘|V|-1+k| italic_V | - 1 + italic_k is fixed-parameter tractable with respect to the parameter k𝑘kitalic_k. We achieve this result by reduction to a problem kernel of linear size.

1 Introduction

A parameterized problem ΠΠ\Piroman_Π can be considered as a set of pairs (I,k)𝐼𝑘(I,k)( italic_I , italic_k ) where I𝐼Iitalic_I is the problem instance and k𝑘kitalic_k (usually an integer) is the parameter. ΠΠ\Piroman_Π is called fixed-parameter tractable (FPT) if membership of (I,k)𝐼𝑘(I,k)( italic_I , italic_k ) in ΠΠ\Piroman_Π can be decided in time O⁢(f⁢(k)⁢|I|c)𝑂𝑓𝑘superscript𝐼𝑐O(f(k)|I|^{c})italic_O ( italic_f ( italic_k ) | italic_I | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where |I|𝐼|I|| italic_I | is the size of I𝐼Iitalic_I, f⁢(k)𝑓𝑘f(k)italic_f ( italic_k ) is a computable function, and c𝑐citalic_c is a constant independent from k𝑘kitalic_k and I𝐼Iitalic_I.

Let G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) be a graph. An ordering of G𝐺Gitalic_G is a bijection α:V→{1,2,…,|V|}.:𝛼→𝑉12…𝑉\alpha:\ V\mbox{$\rightarrow$}\{1,2,\ldots,|V|\}.italic_α : italic_V → { 1 , 2 , … , | italic_V | } . We denote the set of orderings of G𝐺Gitalic_G by OR⁢(G)OR𝐺\mbox{OR}(G)OR ( italic_G ). For a vertex v𝑣vitalic_v in G𝐺Gitalic_G, its neighborhood is N⁢(v)={u∈V:u⁢v∈E}𝑁𝑣conditional-set𝑢𝑉𝑢𝑣𝐸N(v)=\{u\in V:\ uv\in E\}italic_N ( italic_v ) = { italic_u ∈ italic_V : italic_u italic_v ∈ italic_E } and its closed neighborhood is N⁢[v]=N⁢(v)∪{v}.𝑁delimited-[]𝑣𝑁𝑣𝑣N[v]=N(v)\cup\{v\}.italic_N [ italic_v ] = italic_N ( italic_v ) ∪ { italic_v } . The profile of a vertex z𝑧zitalic_z of G𝐺Gitalic_G in an ordering α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of G𝐺Gitalic_G is prfα(G,z)=α(z)−min{α(w) : w∈N[z]}).\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G,z)=\alpha(z)-\min\{\alpha(w)\mbox{ : }w\in N[z]\}).prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_z ) = italic_α ( italic_z ) - roman_min { italic_α ( italic_w ) : italic_w ∈ italic_N [ italic_z ] } ) . The profile of a set Z⊆V𝑍𝑉Z\subseteq Vitalic_Z ⊆ italic_V in an ordering α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of G𝐺Gitalic_G is prfα⁢(G,Z)=∑z∈Zprfα⁢(G,z).subscriptprf𝛼𝐺𝑍subscript𝑧𝑍subscriptprf𝛼𝐺𝑧\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G,Z)=\sum_{z\in Z}\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G,z).prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_Z ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z ∈ italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_z ) . The profile of an ordering α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of G𝐺Gitalic_G is prfα⁢(G)=prfα⁢(G,V).subscriptprf𝛼𝐺subscriptprf𝛼𝐺𝑉\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G)=\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G,V).prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) = prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_V ) . An ordering α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of G𝐺Gitalic_G is optimal if prfα⁢(G)=min⁡{prfβ⁢(G):β∈OR⁢(G)}.subscriptprf𝛼𝐺:subscriptprf𝛽𝐺𝛽OR𝐺\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G)=\min\{\mbox{prf}_{\beta}(G):\ \beta\in\mbox{OR}(G)\}.prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) = roman_min { prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) : italic_β ∈ OR ( italic_G ) } . If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is optimal, then prf⁢(G)=prfα⁢(G)prf𝐺subscriptprf𝛼𝐺\mbox{prf}(G)=\mbox{prf}_{\alpha}(G)prf ( italic_G ) = prf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) is called the profile of G.𝐺G.italic_G .

In [4] Fomin and Golovach established equivalence of prf⁢(G)prf𝐺\mbox{prf}(G)prf ( italic_G ) to other parameters including one important in graph searching. Further areas of application of the profile and equivalent parameters include computational biology [2, 6], archaeology [9] and clone fingerprinting [8]. The following is a well-known NP-complete problem [3, 10].

Minimum Profile Problem (MPP)
Instance: A graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) and a positive integer k𝑘kitalic_k.
Question: Does G𝐺Gitalic_G have an ordering of profile ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k?

In fact this problem is equivalent to the following problem that have been proved to be NP-complete even earlier (see [5]). A graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) is interval if we can associate each vertex v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in Vitalic_v ∈ italic_V with a closed interval Ivsubscript𝐼𝑣I_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the real line such that two distinct vertices x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y are adjacent in G𝐺Gitalic_G if and only if Ix∩Iy≠∅.subscript𝐼𝑥subscript𝐼𝑦I_{x}\cap I_{y}\neq\emptyset.italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ∅ .

Interval Graph Completion (IGC)
Instance: A graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) and a positive integer k≥|E|𝑘𝐸k\geq|E|italic_k ≥ | italic_E |.
Question: Is there a supergraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of G𝐺Gitalic_G such that G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an interval graph and it contains at most k𝑘kitalic_k edges?

The equivalence between MPP and IGC follows from the next result:

Theorem 1.1

[1] For any graph G𝐺Gitalic_G prf⁢(G)prf𝐺\mbox{prf}(G)prf ( italic_G ) equals the smallest number of edges in an interval supergraph of G𝐺Gitalic_G.

Thus, for every graph G𝐺Gitalic_G, prf⁢(E⁢(G))≥|E|.prf𝐸𝐺𝐸\mbox{prf}(E(G))\geq|E|.prf ( italic_E ( italic_G ) ) ≥ | italic_E | . Hence, the following parameterized problem is FPT.

Profile Problem (PP)
Instance: A graph G=(V,E).𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E).italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) . Parameter: A positive integer k𝑘kitalic_k.
Question: Does G𝐺Gitalic_G have an ordering of profile ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k?

Several authors consider the following much more interesting and problem; in fact, it is unknown whether the problem is FPT (private communications with L. Cai, F. Fomin and H. Kaplan).

Profile Above Guaranteed Value (PAGV)
Instance: A graph G=(V,E).𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E).italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) . Parameter: A positive integer k𝑘kitalic_k.
Question: Does G𝐺Gitalic_G have an ordering of profile ≤|E|+kabsent𝐸𝑘\leq|E|+k≤ | italic_E | + italic_k?

Unfortunately, we are not able to determine the complexity of this problem. In this paper, we consider a somewhat weaker version of MPAGV. We restrict ourselves to connected graphs (the case of general graphs can be reduced to connected graphs). Since |E|≥|V|−1𝐸𝑉1|E|\geq|V|-1| italic_E | ≥ | italic_V | - 1 for a connected graph G=(V,E),𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E),italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) , consider the following:

Profile Above Vertex Guaranteed Value (PAVGV)
Instance: A connected graph G=(V,E).𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E).italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) . Parameter: A positive integer k𝑘kitalic_k.
Question: Does G𝐺Gitalic_G have an ordering of profile ≤|V|−1+kabsent𝑉1𝑘\leq|V|-1+k≤ | italic_V | - 1 + italic_k?

This problem is of interest also because of Problem VAP by Serna and Thilikos [11] (see Section 5). We will prove by means of a kernelization scheme that the problem PAVGV is fixed-parameter tractable.

2 Preliminary Results

Lemma 2.2

[10] (i) If G𝐺Gitalic_G is a connected graph with n𝑛nitalic_n vertices, then prf⁢(G)≥n−1.prf𝐺𝑛1\mbox{prf}(G)\geq n-1.prf ( italic_G ) ≥ italic_n - 1 .

Theorem 2.5 gives a lower bound of the profile of a 2-edge-connected graph, which is important for our FPT algorithm. Lin and Yuan [10] used a concise and elegant argument to show that prf⁢(G)≥k⁢(2⁢n−k−1)/2prf𝐺𝑘2𝑛𝑘12\mbox{prf}(G)\geq k(2n-k-1)/2prf ( italic_G ) ≥ italic_k ( 2 italic_n - italic_k - 1 ) / 2 for every k𝑘kitalic_k-connected graph G𝐺Gitalic_G of order n𝑛nitalic_n. Their argument uses Menger’s Theorem in a clever way, yet the argument cannot be used to prove our bound. Instead of Menger’s Theorem we will apply the following well-known decomposition of 2-edge-connected graphs (see, e.g., Theorem 4.2.10 in [12]) called a closed-ear decomposition.

A bridgeless component of a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G is a maximal induced subgraph of G𝐺Gitalic_G with no bridges. 4 Kernelization

For technical reasons, in this section we will deal with a special kind of weighted graphs, but they will be nothing else but compact representations of (unweighted) graphs.

We consider a weighted graph G=(V,E,ρ)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝜌G=(V,E,\rho)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_ρ ) whose vertices v𝑣vitalic_v of degree 1111 have an arbitrary positive integral weight ρ⁢(v)𝜌𝑣\rho(v)italic_ρ ( italic_v ), vertices u𝑢uitalic_u of degree greater than one have weight ρ⁢(u)=1𝜌𝑢1\rho(u)=1italic_ρ ( italic_u ) = 1. The weight ρ⁢(G)𝜌𝐺\rho(G)italic_ρ ( italic_G ) of G=(V,E,ρ)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝜌G=(V,E,\rho)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_ρ ) is the sum of weights of all vertices of G𝐺Gitalic_G. An ordering of a weighted graph G=(V,E,ρ)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝜌G=(V,E,\rho)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_ρ ) is an injective mapping α:V→{1,…,ρ⁢(G)}:𝛼→𝑉1…𝜌𝐺\alpha:V\rightarrow\{1,\dots,\rho(G)\}italic_α : italic_V → { 1 , … , italic_ρ ( italic_G ) } such that for every vertex v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in Vitalic_v ∈ italic_V of degree 1111 we have α⁢(v)≠ρ⁢(G)𝛼𝑣𝜌𝐺\alpha(v)\neq\rho(G)italic_α ( italic_v ) ≠ italic_ρ ( italic_G ) and for all u∈V𝑢𝑉u\in Vitalic_u ∈ italic_V we have α⁢(u)∉{α⁢(v)+1,…,α⁢(v)+ρ⁢(v)−1}𝛼𝑢𝛼𝑣1…𝛼𝑣𝜌𝑣1\alpha(u)\notin\{\alpha(v)+1,\dots,\alpha(v)+\rho(v)-1\}italic_α ( italic_u ) ∉ { italic_α ( italic_v ) + 1 , … , italic_α ( italic_v ) + italic_ρ ( italic_v ) - 1 }. The profile prf⁢(G)prf𝐺\mbox{prf}(G)prf ( italic_G ) of a weighted graph is defined exactly as the profile of an unweighted graph.

Let v𝑣vitalic_v be a vertex of a (weighted) graph G𝐺Gitalic_G. Corollary 4.6

The problem PAVGV is fixed-parameter tractable.

Remark 4.7

We see that PAVGV can be solved in time O⁢(|V|2+f⁢(k)),𝑂superscript𝑉2𝑓𝑘O(|V|^{2}+f(k)),italic_O ( | italic_V | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ( italic_k ) ) , where f⁢(k)=(12+6)!𝑓𝑘126f(k)=(12+6)!italic_f ( italic_k ) = ( 12 + 6 ) !. It would be interesting to significantly decrease f⁢(k),𝑓𝑘f(k),italic_f ( italic_k ) , but even as it is now our algorithm is of practical interest because the kernel produced by the two kernelization rules can be solved using fast heuristics.

5 NP-completeness

Serna and Thilikos [11] asked whether the following problem is FPT.

Vertex Average Profile (VAP)
Instance: A graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ). Parameter: A positive integer k𝑘kitalic_k.
Question: Does G𝐺Gitalic_G have an ordering of profile ≤k⁢|V|absent𝑘𝑉\leq k|V|≤ italic_k | italic_V |?

The following result was announced in [7] without a proof. It implies that VAP is not FPT unless P=NP.
